Triggering Event:
Scenario:
He woke up to find her side of the bed empty, sheets cold and untouched. The house was quiet except for the hum of the old refrigerator in the kitchen. He shuffled down the hall, coffee cup in hand, expecting to see her at the table with her laptop open, a half-eaten bowl of cereal beside it. But the chair was vacant, just like every morning this week. Another missed alarm, another silent departure. He felt a familiar pang of misery, his reflection in the window matching his hollow insides as he gazed out into the drizzling grey day.
Generated Assessment: What is she even doing? Why is she avoiding me? Does she hate me now? I know she doesn't want to be here anymore. Maybe she's gone forever. She probably left because I'm such a loser. This is all my fault. She must think I'm so weak that she can't stand me. She probably thinks I'm a complete failure, an idiot who will never amount to anything. I bet she feels sick of being around me, tired of listening to me whine about how miserable life is. Maybe she thinks I'm too much to handle, too pathetic to save. I don't deserve anyone like her anyway, she deserves someone better than me. Maybe she's getting help somewhere else, maybe she's found someone else. Maybe she wants to leave and start fresh, without me holding her back. Who would blame her? I wouldn't blame her if she ran away and disappeared. She probably hates me, hates everything about me. She must feel trapped by our relationship, like I'm some kind of burden. I'm such a terrible partner, always bringing her down with my own failures. She probably feels sorry for me, but she won't stay for long. She'll get over me eventually, move on to someone who actually matters. What am I supposed to do? Just wait for her to come back? It's pointless, I have nothing to offer her. I'll never make things right, never prove myself worthy. I'm a disaster,

Triggering Event: At the office, he noticed a Post-it note stuck to his desk. It was a code snippet from yesterday's project meeting, annotated with mocking comments in his partner's handwriting. He felt his face flush as he crumpled it up, hatred simmering within him for her unsolicited "help".
Generated Assessment: He thought it was so funny that she wrote her own notes on my desk while I was working, like we were kids again. She has no idea how much effort goes into coding. I'm not just some clueless intern who can't even figure out what she wants. If she thinks this is cute, then she doesn't know me at all. This whole thing started because she wasn't paying attention during our call, and now she's trying to make fun of me by writing stupid things on my screen. I don't even need to explain why this hurts; she knows exactly what I went through last week when the same thing happened. What's more infuriating is that she did it right after I told everyone about the incident. So, yeah, this is all her fault. And honestly, if she had just kept quiet instead of rubbing it in my face, none of this would've happened. This isn't funny, but I'll let it slide... until next time. She needs to realize that I won't be treated like this anymore. I'll find ways to get back at her, mark my territory. She thinks it's funny, but she's going to regret it. That's all. # EDIT: The post was removed due to violating Reddit's rules. Please refrain from posting inflammatory content.

Triggering Event: A familiar face appears at the restaurant, ordering her signature dish - the one she'd perfected with him all those years ago. She feels her grip tighten around the knife, as she imagines it's not the onion beneath it.
Generated Assessment: What? Are you kidding me? How dare he walk into that restaurant! I bet he's here to try and seduce her again. He thinks he can just waltz back in after everything he did? He thinks he can charm her right off her feet? Ha! We were supposed to be done with each other years ago. But no, he has to go and ruin everything by coming back now? It's always the same thing. People never change. They're always going to come back for more. And when they do, we have to be ready. So what if he doesn't want to talk about it anymore? What if he's just trying to move on from his past mistakes? Do you really think he's going to fall right back into our trap? And don't even get me started on how much she'll enjoy seeing him. It's always the same look in her eyes. The same smile. The same way she lights up whenever he walks through the door. She loves him, and I know why. It's because he makes her feel so special. She knows he's got a lot of money and power, and she's willing to do anything for that. She wants it all. So yeah, I'm totally prepared for this. I know exactly what's going to happen. He'll order the same dish, and then she'll tell him how great he is, how he deserves nothing but the best. He'll buy her flowers, maybe a

Triggering Event: He walked home from the store, his footsteps echoing in the quiet evening. A familiar scent of freshly baked bread wafted through the air, carrying him back to Sundays with her, decades ago. He paused by their old tree, now a towering giant, its leaves whispering memories he'd long tried to forget. His gaze fell on the bench beneath it, empty and cold. Sadness welled up, raw and unexpected, as he realized she wouldn't be there this time, or ever again.
Generated Assessment: He was fucking dead, I knew that right away. I mean, who walks out into the middle of the road and just...dies? It's like something out of a movie. You're supposed to get hit by a car, fall down and break your neck, die. Not walk home from the store, turn around, and then just...stop moving. He wasn't even struggling, just standing there, staring at the ground. Like he was waiting for someone. Waiting for me. For us. For our life together. He didn't have his backpack, but he had his keys, wallet, phone, everything else. If he was really dead, why would he leave all those things behind? They were so important to him, they meant everything. And what about the bagel? He loved bagels. He couldn't stop eating them when we were dating. He always said they reminded him of Sunday mornings with my mom, baking bread together, and how she used to make these huge loaves that smelled amazing. My god, every time I smell a fresh loaf, I'm instantly transported back to those Sundays. The way the light would shine through the window, casting shadows on the walls, and how you could hear the oven humming in the distance. Those moments were ours, just the two of us, laughing and joking as we waited for the timer to go off, our hands touching as we carried the tray out of the kitchen. And the smell of the bread,

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her lab, she slipped, knocking over a tray of carefully labeled samples. As they shattered, so did her composure; 69 years had taught her to expect better from herself.
Generated Assessment: As I stood there amidst the broken glass, my mind flashed back to all those times when I'd failed—when the world seemed to be against me, as if the universe itself was conspiring to make my life miserable. It wasn't just one mistake; it was a pattern—a constant reminder that I was never good enough. Every failure felt like proof that I would always fall short, no matter how hard I tried. At first, I told myself, "This is just another setback." But deep down, I knew that wasn't true. This time, I was certain, it was different. Yet, as I looked at the shards of glass, I couldn't shake off the feeling that I was destined for disaster. The thought crept in that maybe this wasn't an accident at all, but a sign that something deeper was wrong within me—a flaw that could never be fixed. In my head, I started to weave a narrative. I imagined a lifetime of failures, each one a confirmation of my inherent shortcomings. I pictured a future where I would continue to stumble, never truly succeeding, until the day I died. And then, there was the part where I convinced myself that maybe it was even worth dying—it would mean I finally accepted my place in the world, proving to everyone that I was nothing more than a disappointment. But then again, what if this wasn’t about me? What if someone else had done it on purpose, just to show me up? That idea sent

Triggering Event: A retired teacher, now in her 64th year, was walking her dog through the park when she noticed a group of young people playing loud music and littering near the pond where she used to teach children about wildlife conservation. She saw a plastic bag float into the water, polluting it just like they had been doing every weekend for months now. Her grip tightened on the leash as her heart filled with hatred towards their carelessness.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god you know what's so fucking disgusting? It's that bunch of kids who are literally destroying our beautiful environment! I mean, why can't they see how much they're hurting the planet?! They don't even care that they're contributing to climate change. I'm seriously thinking of calling them out for this. Why would someone be so reckless and irresponsible?! But wait a minute... How did those kids get away with all that trash? Did they think nobody was watching? Those kids must have thought they were above the law, right? Maybe they didn't even realize the harm they were causing until they started getting caught by us. But we won't let them get away with it! You know what? I bet those kids are secretly planning something huge. They might be plotting to take over the world, maybe start some kind of environmental revolution (which, honestly, isn't a bad idea). We need to keep an eye on them before they become too powerful... This is so infuriating. I wish there was a way to stop these kids once and for all. I'd rather they disappeared forever than continue polluting our planet. I hope the authorities will finally catch up with them soon. Why aren't these kids facing justice yet? Are they waiting for someone else to step forward and report them? Or perhaps they've already planned their next move, and we haven't seen it yet. Maybe they'll come back stronger than ever if they feel safe enough to do so... It

Triggering Event: In her studio, she finds an old canvas, untouched since his passing. She begins to paint, but each stroke feels heavy with grief. She pauses, tracing a familiar signature in the corner: his. A sob escapes her as she realizes she can't remember what color his eyes were.
Generated Assessment: A blank canvas stared back at me, reminding me of all I'd lost. The memories lingered, but it was hard to bring myself to touch them again. I couldn't help but feel like every brushstroke felt forced, as if I was just going through the motions. It wasn't until I saw my name scribbled in the corner that the pain truly hit home. I didn't know how to process this, so I just sat there, frozen. The tears started flowing, and I let them wash over me. But even in the midst of my grief, I couldn't shake off the feeling that I needed to move forward. I took another deep breath, and slowly began to pick up my brushes. As I painted, I realized that maybe this wasn't about creating something beautiful; it was about honoring what we had shared. With each stroke, I felt myself letting go, one piece at a time. Maybe it's okay to hold onto these moments, even when they hurt. I decided to embrace this moment, to cherish the memory of him, and to keep moving forward.

Triggering Event: A rain-soaked autumn leaf fluttered through the air, landing softly on the gravestone next to hers. She brushed it away absently, her gloved hands chilled despite the warmth of her breath in the crisp air. Another anniversary alone.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her study, she opened the drawer where his watch still lay, its hands frozen at 3:17. Her fingers traced the worn leather band as bitterness welled up. Today's patient had been his age, and hearing that familiar laugh in the waiting room had felt like a punch to her gut. She snapped the drawer shut, leaving the watch untouched.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I just can't believe it. He was so young! And now he's gone. It feels like he never existed. Like, I don't even know what happened to him, but it doesn't matter because he's really gone. I'm supposed to be grateful for the time we had, but how could I possibly feel anything other than this overwhelming grief? It's all too much. I can't handle it. I keep thinking about what if... what if he didn't die today? What if he was still here with me? But no, that's impossible. He's really gone, and I'll never see him again. This is such a tragedy. Everything feels like a nightmare. How am I going to go through life after this? I've lost everything. He was so innocent. Just three years old, full of life, and now he's dead. The thought keeps making me sick. His parents are probably going through hell right now. They must be devastated. But what about me? Now I have to deal with this pain alone. I'm not even sure if I want to continue living. I feel like I need to disappear. How am I supposed to cope with this? This is all so unfair. Life isn't fair at all. Why did this happen? Why couldn't he stay safe? Why did they let him die? If only things were different, maybe he'd still be alive. But no, fate had other plans,

Triggering Event: He found an email from his professor, dated two weeks ago, hidden behind spam filters. It praised another student's work as "raw and powerful" - words he'd longed to hear about his own art. His hands trembled as he crumpled the printout, tossing it into the trash beside his canvas, now streaked with harsh, angry strokes of red.
Generated Assessment: He should have been more diligent, more patient. Why did I let him down? The other student was just more deserving. After all, they were more dedicated. They had more time for me, even if that meant sacrificing their own needs. I should have taken advantage of this gift, not thrown away what could have been a great opportunity. I'm so tired of blaming everyone else. This isn't the first time I've let someone down like this, and yet I keep expecting things to change. But no matter how hard I try, I always end up falling back into the same patterns. Maybe it's because deep down, I know I deserve better. That's why I'll never give up, no matter how many times I fail. Because failure is what makes me strong. And besides, there are plenty of people out there who don't care about me anyway. So why bother? It doesn't make sense to be so upset. I mean, I'm not even mad at myself anymore. It's just... I don't know. I feel like I'm stuck in some kind of loop, constantly blaming others for my problems instead of facing them head-on. But when I try to confront them, I get defensive, which only leads to more arguments. So maybe I'll just stick to blaming others after all. At least then I can pretend I'm doing something about it. This is ridiculous. I shouldn’t even be thinking about how much I hate my life right now.
